items.title: A flag that makes twine complain about existing distribution only when it differs from the one that's being uploaded
items.body:
Hello!

Twine has a `--skip-existing` flag, which stops it from complaining about the server refusing to overwrite a distribution.

I want to propose a similar feature, but a bit more stringent when it comes to ensuring, that the right content is on the remote: a flag that will make Twine fail if the distribution to upload is already in the repository *and* has a different checksum.

See the details below. I'd be happy to create a PR for this, if there's a chance it would be accepted, since it impacts my daily work.

### Use cases

Suppose we have a CI scheme, where a commit to a release branch of a VCS triggers a build and an upload. This works well if the version string of the distribution has changed - e.g. `setup.py` was updated correctly in the last set of changes.

There are two possible scenarios, where the upload gets rejected by the server because of an existing distribution with the same name:
 * The build result has changed, but the distribution version didn't: CI should fail and scream at maintainers. This makes the usage of `--skip-existing` inapplicable for this scheme, as it makes twine silently ignore such errors.
 * The build result has not changed (e.g. we modified `.gitignore`), CI should not complain about PyPI rejecting the files. It should not even attempt to upload the files. To attempt to implement something like this in CI currently, one would have to compare checksums in a pipeline code, which can get messy.

A flag that makes Twine complain about an unchanged version, rather than just duplication, would make the implementation of such scheme a breeze.

This feature would also introduce something akin to idempotence. In projects where a merge to a release branch implies an upload, reintroducing all missing builds would be as simple as running build + upload on all commits in release branches.

### Implementation details
For PyPI-simple APIs, [PEP-503](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0503/) specifies, that the repositories ["SHOULD" add the hash in the URL](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0503/#specification:~:text=.%20The%20URL%20SHOULD%20include%20a%20hash%20in%20the%20form%20of%20a%20URL%20fragment). I verified this behavior on [JFrog Artifactory](https://jfrog.com/artifactory/) and [Sonatype Nexus](https://www.sonatype.com/product-nexus-repository) - both add MD5 checksums to simple's URLs.

Warehouse API provides required data via [releases endpoint](https://warehouse.readthedocs.io/api-reference/json/#release).

For the minority of cases where checksums are not supported, I'd propose that the flag in question triggers a warning, and the behavior falls back to whatever would happen if the flag wasn't there - maybe including the ignoring of errors when `--skip-existing` is present too.

items.title: twine .pypirc doesn't allow for section with space in name.
items.body:
## Your Environment
Thank you for taking the time to report an issue.

To more efficiently resolve this issue, we'd like to know some basic information about your system and setup.

1) Your operating system:
Linux

2) Version of python you are running:
Python 3.6.3

3) How did you install twine? Did you use your operating system's package manager or pip or something else?
pip install twine

4) Version of twine you have installed (include complete output of):
twine version 3.2.0 (pkginfo: 1.5.0.1, requests: 2.22.0, setuptools: 36.5.0, requests-toolbelt: 0.9.1, tqdm: 4.48.0)

5) Which package repository are you targeting?
N/A


## The Issue
twine splits the index-servers with .split() instead of .split("\n")
preventing a .pypirc file from using an index server section with a space in the name.


## Steps to Reproduce
vi test.pypirc
[distutils]
index-servers=a b
[a b]
repository=https://a.b.com/upload
username=test
password=password

python -m twine upload -r 'a b' --config-file test.pypirc ./dist/*

This results in an error InvalidConfiguration: Missing 'a b' section from the configuration file.
it assuming there are 2 index servers [a],[b] instead of one named [a b]

I believe this could be fixed by changing twine/utils.py +71
to split on newline vs spaces. Or use some other parsing to allow for quoted index server "sections"
and update the documentation to enforce new lines between index-servers listed.



Downstream Impact: 
When Project Name contains a space results this results in incompatible .pypirc file.
https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks/TwineAuthenticateV1

items.title: Potential dependency conflicts between twine and requests
items.body:
Hi, as shown in the following full dependency graph of  **_twine_**, **_twine_** requires _**requests**_ (>=2.20)， while the installed version of **_requests-toolbelt_**(0.9.1) requires _**requests>=2.0.1,<3.0.0**_.

According to Pip's “first found wins” installation strategy, _**requests 2.23.0**_ is the actually installed version.  

Although the first found package version _**requests 2.23.0**_ just satisfies the later dependency constraint （_**requests>=2.0.1,<3.0.0**_), it will lead to a build failure once developers release a newer version of requests.

### Dependency tree--------
```
twine - 3.1.1
| +- pkginfo(install version:1.5.0.1 version range:>=1.4.2)
| +- readme-renderer(install version:25.0 version range:>=21.0)
| +- requests(install version:2.23.0 version range:>=2.20)
| | +- certifi(install version:2020.4.5.1 version range:>=2017.4.17)
| | +- chardet(install version:3.0.4 version range:>=3.0.2,<4)
| | +- idna(install version:2.9 version range:>=2.5,<3)
| | +- urllib3(install version:1.25.9 version range:>=1.21.1,<1.26)
| +- requests-toolbelt(install version:0.9.1 version range:>=0.8.0)
| | +- requests(install version:2.23.0 version range:>=2.0.1,<3.0.0)
| | | +- certifi(install version:2020.4.5.1 version range:>=2017.4.17)
| | | +- chardet(install version:3.0.4 version range:>=3.0.2,<4)
| | | +- idna(install version:2.9 version range:>=2.5,<3)
| | | +- urllib3(install version:1.25.9 version range:>=1.21.1,<1.26)
| +- setuptools(install version:46.1.3 version range:>=0.7.0)
| +- tqdm(install version:4.45.0 version range:>=4.14) 
```

Thanks for your attention.
Best,
Neolith

items.title: Adopt linting for docstrings
items.body:
Submitting this for discussion and elaboration. Related to #628.

It seems like it would be helpful to have an enforced style guide in place, even if it means turning off a bunch of rules, and/or white/black-listing files.

Some potentially useful tools:

- [pydocstyle](http://www.pydocstyle.org/en/5.0.2/), maybe via [flake8-docstrings](https://pypi.org/project/flake8-docstrings/)
- [interrogate: Python docstring coverage](https://interrogate.readthedocs.io/en/latest/)

items.title: Rewrite test docstrings

labels.name: testing
labels.description: Test frameworks, tests, etc.

items.body:
There are a number of test docstrings that duplicate the method names, such as:

https://github.com/pypa/twine/blob/24466641263835b2c4599c9f0898deb62f33ef8d/tests/test_register.py#L27-L28

Inspired by https://hynek.me/articles/document-your-tests/ and https://jml.io/pages/test-docstrings.html, I think there's an opportunity for the docstrings to provide more value to future contributors.

I'd suggest starting with one PR, that focuses on one file, with a small number of tests; maybe `test_register.py`. That way we can review and establish patterns.

An example of a rewrite can be seen in https://github.com/pypa/twine/pull/622/commits/9ca14ce0a06d4ee1c41135cc68f0cd61c5749577.

Candidates for rewriting (there might be others):

```
$ grep -r '"""Test' tests/**/test_*.py
tests/test_register.py:    """Test a successful package registration"""
tests/test_register.py:    """Test a repository url redirection during registration"""
tests/test_register.py:    """Test a non-existent package registration"""
tests/test_register.py:    """Test calling main via cli"""
tests/test_repository.py:    """Test that gpg signature structure doesn't change"""
tests/test_repository.py:    """Test that content structure doesn't change"""
tests/test_repository.py:    """Test that iterables structures are changed and flattened"""
tests/test_repository.py:    """Test that setting client certificate is successful"""

tests/test_repository.py:    """Test that a package upload succeeds without bypassing cache"""
tests/test_repository.py:    """Test that a package upload succeeds bypassing cache"""
tests/test_repository.py:    """Test that a package upload fails as safe name and basefilename differ"""
tests/test_repository.py:    """Test that a package is registered successfully"""
tests/test_repository.py:    """Test whether the disable flag is passed to tqdm
tests/test_repository.py:    """Test that retry works while uploading"""
tests/test_repository.py:    """Test that the correct release urls are read"""

```

items.title: Support for API key based authentication from Environment variables
items.body:
This is a feature request affecting all versions on all OSs.

Today, twine supports pulling username and password for authentication from Environment Variables, [as per this documentation](https://twine.readthedocs.io/en/latest/#environment-variables).

I couldn't see any evidence in the codebase of support for API tokens via environment variables for connecting to PyPi for example, as supported in config files for usernames and passwords as per `settings.py`.

I believe reading the API key from an environment variable is elegant for CI based workflows when pushing to a package manager as most CIs have centralized around using environment variables for secret managements.

If this is a feature that you agree on adding, I'm pretty happy to add it.

Thanks!

2) Version of python you are running:

python.org-provided `dmg`s for Python 3.8, 3.7, 3.6, 3.5, 2.7

3) How did you install twine? Did you use your operating system's package manager or pip or something else?

`pip install` and via tox (b/c I tried many ways during debugging)

4) Version of twine you have installed:

v3.1.1

5) Which package repository are you targeting?

PyPI/TestPyPI but it doesn't matter in the context of this issue because it's about `twine check`, not uploading the dists.

## The Issue

So I'm in progress of packaging platform-specific dists. I was building them
using `pip wheel` in a tox env and then running `delocate` outside.
Then I started moving `delocate` into a toxenv (separate) and after that `twine check` started spitting out this traceback:
```python-traceback
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.8/lib/python3.8/runpy.py", line 193, in _run_module_as_main
    return _run_code(code, main_globals, None,
  File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.8/lib/python3.8/runpy.py", line 86, in _run_code
    exec(code, run_globals)
  File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.8/lib/python3.8/site-packages/twine/__main__.py", line 31, in <module>
    sys.exit(main())
  File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.8/lib/python3.8/site-packages/twine/__main__.py", line 25, in main
    return dispatch(sys.argv[1:])
  File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.8/lib/python3.8/site-packages/twine/cli.py", line 74, in dispatch
    return main(args.args)
  File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.8/lib/python3.8/site-packages/twine/commands/check.py", line 158, in main
    return check(args.dists)
  File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.8/lib/python3.8/site-packages/twine/commands/check.py", line 121, in check
    warnings, is_ok = _check_file(filename, render_warning_stream)
  File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.8/lib/python3.8/site-packages/twine/commands/check.py", line 73, in _check_file
    package = PackageFile.from_filename(filename, comment=None)
  File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.8/lib/python3.8/site-packages/twine/package.py", line 104, in from_filename
    py_version = meta.py_version
  File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.8/lib/python3.8/site-packages/twine/wheel.py", line 47, in py_version
    return wheel_info.group("pyver")
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'group'
Checking dist/*.whl: 
##[error]Process completed with exit code 1.
```
_(here's that line in src: https://github.com/pypa/twine/blob/3.1.1/twine/wheel.py#L47)_

Now, I understand that it looks like a bug in `delocate` (or/and maybe the isolation that tox creates for it) but still twine should error out more gracefully.

Imagine my surprise when I discovered that this has been "fixed" in master just a day before I started seeing it: https://github.com/pypa/twine/commit/7111240b04f022d5366af7297b9e81c63d76fb6d#diff-c533b522e297bb77ebe6ed9089c754beR48-R51.

I'm not sure if it counts as a fix because it's a commit that adds annotations and the change looks like a side-effect, plus no tests for this were added. Should it return `any` when the regex doesn't match? This is still to be identified.

## Steps to Reproduce

This is all I have atm: https://github.com/ansible/pylibssh/runs/625207843?check_suite_focus=true#step:15:68

items.title: Bug in twine.repository.upload related to print during retries
items.body:
In `twine.repository.upload` method, we use the default `max_redirects` value (5) in the print statement within the retry loop, but we should be using the value passed in the function.

https://github.com/pypa/twine/blob/2c30b1e9c7936a6edd2e54c44852b58461fbc771/twine/repository.py#L190-L196

items.title: Vague exception message in twine.wheel.read and twine.wininst

https://github.com/pypa/twine/blob/f61707b93a4f5dd89dfdd22db1acb846b8932b9c/twine/wheel.py#L55

items.title: Potential improvement for checking repository URL scheme/protocol
items.body:
## Your Environment
Thank you for taking the time to report an issue.

To more efficiently resolve this issue, we'd like to know some basic information about your system and setup.

1) Your operating system: Mac OS Catalina: 10.15.4 (19E266)

2) Version of python you are running:
``` bash
python --version
Python 3.8.2
```

3) How did you install twine? Did you use your operating system's package manager or pip or something else?

I followed the instruction in Contributing docs
where I cloned the repo, created a virtual env and installed twine in editable mode

4) Version of twine you have installed (include complete output of):
``` bash
twine --version
twine version 3.1.2.dev46+gf61707b (pkginfo: 1.5.0.1, requests: 2.23.0, setuptools: 41.2.0, requests-toolbelt: 0.9.1, tqdm: 4.44.1)
```

5) Which package repository are you targeting?

N/A . I am not targeting any repo

## The Issue
Please describe the issue that you are experiencing.

While adding unit tests to `twine.utils`, I saw that we are doing a check if the protocol is present in the repo url by doing `if "://" in repository_url`, but I think this also allow for invalid URLs like `foo://bar.baz` 

```
$ twine upload --repository-url foo://bar.baz dist/*
Uploading distributions to foo://bar.baz
Enter your username: 
Enter your password: 
Uploading twine-3.1.2.dev36+gf7402e0.d20200418.tar.gz
  0%|                                                                                                                    | 0.00/163k [00:00<?, ?B/s]
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/devesh/twine/.env/bin/twine", line 11, in <module>
    load_entry_point('twine', 'console_scripts', 'twine')()
  File "/Users/devesh/twine/twine/__main__.py", line 25, in main
    return cli.dispatch(sys.argv[1:])
  File "/Users/devesh/twine/twine/cli.py", line 67, in dispatch
    return main(args.args)
  File "/Users/devesh/twine/twine/commands/upload.py", line 129, in main
    return upload(upload_settings, args.dists)
  File "/Users/devesh/twine/twine/commands/upload.py", line 82, in upload
    resp = repository.upload(package)
  File "/Users/devesh/twine/twine/repository.py", line 184, in upload
    resp = self._upload(package)
  File "/Users/devesh/twine/twine/repository.py", line 170, in _upload
    resp = self.session.post(
  File "/Users/devesh/twine/.env/lib/python3.8/site-packages/requests/sessions.py", line 578, in post
    return self.request('POST', url, data=data, json=json, **kwargs)
  File "/Users/devesh/twine/.env/lib/python3.8/site-packages/requests/sessions.py", line 530, in request
    resp = self.send(prep, **send_kwargs)
  File "/Users/devesh/twine/.env/lib/python3.8/site-packages/requests/sessions.py", line 637, in send
    adapter = self.get_adapter(url=request.url)
  File "/Users/devesh/twine/.env/lib/python3.8/site-packages/requests/sessions.py", line 728, in get_adapter
    raise InvalidSchema("No connection adapters were found for {!r}".format(url))
requests.exceptions.InvalidSchema: No connection adapters were found for 'foo://bar.baz'
```

I think this can be improved by checking if we get a valid scheme `(http, https etc)` by using [urllib.parse.urlparse](https://docs.python.org/3/library/urllib.parse.html#urllib.parse.urlparse)

items.title: Avoid suggesting to upload dist/* in documentations
items.body:
Some background info into this:  So a few days ago I asked my collaborator to handle our project's release for the first time, and he blindly followed twine's README, especially the part of `twine upload dist/*`, which lead to a bunch of eggs having been uploaded to our index.  Of course the fault is in our communication (I told him to only upload the latest release's sdist, but he was careless), but I wonder if we can avoid documenting dangerous copy-pastable commands in the docs.

For more experienced maintainers who know what they're doing, it's obvious that the command is there to only suggest that packages usually in `dist`, andone can use Twine to upload things in there.  However, for newbies, the amount of information might be overwhelming to figure that out at their first glance.

I don't have any specific suggestion to replace the current instruction though.

items.title: Reformat error message output

labels.name: question
labels.description: Discussion/decision needed from maintainers

items.body:
Currently, Twine displays error messages like this:

```
$ twine upload --repository testpypi -u __token__ -p pypi-token dist/*
Uploading distributions to https://test.pypi.org/legacy/
Uploading example-pkg-bhrutledge-0.0.4a3.tar.gz
100%|██████████████████████████████████████| 4.53k/4.53k [00:00<00:00, 19.0kB/s]
NOTE: Try --verbose to see response content.
HTTPError: 403 Client Error: Invalid or non-existent authentication information. See https://test.pypi.org/help/#invalid-auth for details for url: https://test.pypi.org/legacy/
```

I think something like this would be more helpful (though I'm not committed to this exact format):

```
Uploading distributions to https://test.pypi.org/legacy/
Uploading example-pkg-bhrutledge-0.0.4a3.tar.gz
100%|██████████████████████████████████████| 4.53k/4.53k [00:00<00:00, 19.0kB/s]

ERROR from https://test.pypi.org/legacy/: 403 Forbidden 
Invalid or non-existent authentication information. See https://test.pypi.org/help/#invalid-auth for details.
NOTE: Try --verbose to see response content.
```

For errors like this one from Warehouse, I think this makes the source and potential resolution more obvious, and might have mitigated issues like #577 and #424.

This might be a significant restructuring, since it seems like "expected" errors are displayed by a catch-all `except`:

https://github.com/pypa/twine/blob/f7402e0d2e1c1e6ecde61dc8bcba515b807a48a0/twine/__main__.py#L23-L27

Related:

- [Refactor/normalize exceptions · Issue #586](https://github.com/pypa/twine/issues/586)
- [Use red text when printing errors on command line · Issue #511](https://github.com/pypa/twine/issues/511)

items.title: ENH: setup.py register --list-classifiers
items.body:
A command that lists the PyPI trove classifiers just like `python setup.py register --list-classifiers` (which doesn't work anymore) in order to list the trove classifiers such that they can be grepped. 

These are the lists:
- https://pypi.org/classifiers/ (HTML)
- https://pypi.org/pypi?%3Aaction=list_classifiers (TXT)
- https://github.com/pypa/trove-classifiers/blob/master/trove_classifiers/__init__.py (Python module containing a list of strs)


Workaround:
```bash
curl -s 'https://pypi.org/pypi?%3Aaction=list_classifiers' \
  | grep -Ei 'development status|license'

```

items.title: Can't use a password if client certificate is used

labels.name: support
labels.description: Users asking for help using twine

items.body:
Bug introduced by https://github.com/pypa/twine/pull/483

I'm trying to upload to a private pypi server. There is a client-certificate SSL reverse proxy in front, and the pypi server has user authentication. 

I used to be able to have both of these, but I can't upload anymore since #483.

Looking at https://github.com/pypa/twine/issues/336, I don't think any code change was necessary. Now that the --non-interactive option is available.

Can #483 be reverted please?

items.title: Suggestion: add an env-var to define --config-file default location/value

labels.name: question
labels.description: Discussion/decision needed from maintainers

items.body:
When running in CI, which is a standard use case for twine, it is often considered best practice to use a separate `.pypirc` file per job meaning that the `--config-file` cli arg is used a lot.

It would be nice to have an env-var such as `TWINE_CONFIG_FILE` to set the default for that globally, thus changing the default requirement for `.pypirc` to be at the home directory.

items.title: Rely on SCM metatdata for version
items.body:
Currently, the package version is declared statically in source code (`twine/__init__.py` or `setup.py` if #528 is accepted). That means except for the tagged releases, the `__version__` is deceiving about what version is in use (current master is "2.0.0" but has different behavior from the released 2.0.0).

Moreover, by storing the version statically in the codebase, it becomes necessary to add a commit and change the version number before any release. It's a manual step that's prone to mistakes.

If instead the project were to rely on tags SCM metadata from which to derive a version, it eliminates that manual step and allows the version to derive from the state of the repo, reflecting the version from the tag (for tagged commits), or deriving a pre/post release for other commits or a dirty checkout.

items.title: Unconditionally require keyring
items.body:
In #519, it's become apparent that the optional importing of keyring adds a substantial burden to the project's maintenance, especially after adding type hints. Previously, the main way to opt out of keyring support in twine has been to avoid installing keyring, but as subsequent work showed (#338), that interface was insufficient.

The intention of keyring is to be installed and only to have any non-degenerate behavior when the environment indicates such behavior is relevant (i.e. a meaningful password system is present).

In [keyring 15.1](https://keyring.readthedocs.io/en/latest/history.html), released over a year ago, an additional feature, the `--disable` keyword was added for a user to easily disable keyring functionality.

I'd like to consider for twine to unconditionally depend on keyring and rely on `--disable` for users that require to disable this functionality.

items.title: Cannot upload Python wheels with direct references in the Requires-Dist field
items.body:
## The Issue

At work we are trying to upload a Python wheel with a direct reference (URI) in its {package}.dist-info/METADATA file (`Requires-Dist` field) to a _private_ index server using `twine`:

> Requires-Dist: keras-contrib @ git+https://www.github.com/keras-team/keras-contrib.git

But during the upload:

```
$ twine upload --repository {...} --config-file {...}/.pypirc {...}/dist/*
```

we get the following error:

> HTTPError: 400 Client Error: Bad Request - Packages with direct (URL) references in Requires-Dist are not allowed.

A similar issue was opened on the Github repository of `pip`, but this time the user could not upload its Python wheel to a _public_ index server (PyPI) instead of a private one: https://github.com/pypa/pip/issues/6301

[PEP 566](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0566/) has been revised to make it explicit that _all_ Python tools should support direct references in the `Requires-Dist` field (only "public index servers MAY prohibit strict version matching clauses or direct references in this field"), so it seems that `twine` is not compliant yet: https://github.com/python/peps/issues/763

@dstufft, is this feature planned?

## Environment

- Windows Server 2016
- Python 3.6.8
- Twine 1.13.0
- Pip 19.2.1
- Setuptools 40.6.2

`PKG-INFO` file:

> Metadata-Version: 2.1
> Name: {...}

items.title: "403 Client Error" shown only after upload is done
items.body:
Windows 7, Python 3.7.2, twine version 1.13.0 (pkginfo: 1.5.0.1, requests: 2.21.0, setuptools: 41.0.1, requests-toolbelt: 0.9.1, tqdm: 4.31.1)

When getting "403 Client Error" due to mistyped credentials, the error shows only after the upload is complete, which can take 30 seconds. It would be nice if the error would show immediately, without waiting for the upload.

items.title: Twine check fails due to long-description sections

labels.name: support
labels.description: Users asking for help using twine

items.body:
## Your Environment
1) Your operating system:
Windows 10

2) Version of python you are running:
Python 3.7.3

3) How did you install twine? Did you use your operating system's package manager or pip or something else?
pip install twine

4) Version of twine you have installed (include complete output of):
twine version 1.13.0 (pkginfo: 1.5.0.1, requests: 2.22.0, setuptools: 30.4.0,
requests-toolbelt: 0.9.1, tqdm: 4.32.2)

5) Which package repository are you targeting?
azure-batch-extensions

## The Issue
`twine check`  and also `twine upload` fails to upload long-description with section header. The error message received is 
```
The project's long_description has invalid markup which will not be rendered on PyPI. The following syntax errors were detected:
line 1: Severe: Unexpected section title or transition.

=====
```

Current setup I am testing with is:
```
with open('README.rst', 'r', encoding='utf-8') as f:
    README = f.read()

setup(
    name='azure-batch-extensions',
    version=version,
    description='Microsoft Azure Batch Extended Features',
    long_description_content_type='text/x-rst',
    long_description=README,
    author='Microsoft Corporation',
    author_email='azpycli@microsoft.com',
    url='https://github.com/Azure/azure-batch-cli-extensions',
    classifiers=CLASSIFIERS,
    namespace_packages=[
        'azext'
    ],
    packages=[
        'azext.batch',
        'azext.batch.operations',
        'azext.batch.models'
    ],
    install_requires=DEPENDENCIES,
    extras_require=DEPENDENCIES_27,
)
```

and the README.rst is 
```
title
=====

content
```

Interestingly the following README.rst passes
```
aaa
===

content
```

## Steps to Reproduce
`python setup.py sdist` the above setup in a setup.py
`twine check .\dist\*.tar.gz`

items.title: Allow specifying a password command
items.body:
## Your Environment

1) Your operating system: Debian buster (current “testing”, upcoming release)
2) Version of python you are running: `Python 3.7.3rc1`
3) How did you install twine? In a venv, through `pip`.
4) Version of twine you have installed: `twine version 1.13.0 (pkginfo: 1.5.0.1, requests: 2.21.0, setuptools: 41.0.0, requests-toolbelt: 0.9.1, tqdm: 4.32.1)`
5) Which package repository are you targeting? pypi.org


## The Issue
Currently, the only ways to pass a PyPI password are:
- on the command line or interactively;
- in plaintext in the `.pypirc` file;
- through environment variables, which leads to it being exposed to other processes (and subsequently in core dumps, debug output, ...)

None of this is both convenient and adequately secure.

Please consider supporting a `password-command` option (or somesuch) to specify a command to execute, that outputs the password to use.  This enables easy integration with password managers or the operating system's native keychain, while remaining entirely platform-agnostic.

Note that this is a concerned that was already expressed in pypa/warehouse#994 :
> In addition, the [packaging docs example] encourages users to save their password in plaintext on disk in their `.pypirc`.

items.title: FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: 'gpg': 'gpg'
items.body:
On platform where `gpg` executable does not exist twine failsto sign with an errorl like:
```
FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: 'gpg': 'gpg'
```

This happens even if `gpg2` executable is present and working, use of gpg2 is quite common and twine should be able to prefer instead of the very old gpg.

Adding an alias does not solve the problem

items.title: Twine check incorrectly reports `long_description_content_type` missing

labels.name: support
labels.description: Users asking for help using twine

items.body:
## Your Environment
Thank you for taking the time to report an issue.

To more efficiently resolve this issue, we'd like to know some basic information about your system and setup.

1) Your operating system:
Mac OS X

2) Version of python you are running:
Python 3.7.2

3) How did you install twine? Did you use your operating system's package manager or pip or something else?

`pip install twine==1.13.0`

4) Version of twine you have installed (include complete output of):

*Not working*
```
twine version 1.13.0 (pkginfo: 1.5.0.1, requests: 2.21.0, setuptools: 40.8.0,
requests-toolbelt: 0.9.1, tqdm: 4.31.1)
```

*Working*
```
twine version 1.12.1 (pkginfo: 1.5.0.1, requests: 2.21.0, setuptools: 40.8.0,
requests-toolbelt: 0.9.1, tqdm: 4.31.1)
```

5) Which package repository are you targeting?
PyPI

If you're having issues uploading a specific package, you *must* include a copy of the following:
* The package's `PKG-INFO` file
* A redacted version of your `.pypirc` file (**REMOVE ALL USERNAMES & PASSWORDS BEFORE UPLOADING**)


## The Issue

With Twine 1.13.1 `twine check dist/*` reports
```
Checking distribution dist/3gpp_citations-1.1.2-py3-none-any.whl: warning: `long_description_content_type` missing.  defaulting to `text/x-rst`.
```

and `PKG-INFO` is missing `Description-Content-Type: text/markdown`.
With Twine 1.12.1 `PKG-INFO` correctly contains `Description-Content-Type: text/markdown`

## Steps to Reproduce
If the issue is predictable and consistently reproducible, please list the steps here.

1. Add `long_description_content_type='text/markdown'` to your `setup.py`.
```
setup(
...
    long_description=open('README.md').read(),
    long_description_content_type='text/markdown',
...
)
```

2. Install Twine 1.12.1 and build
```
pip install twine==1.12.1
python setup.py sdist
twine check dist/*
```

This will result in `Checking distribution dist/mypackage.tar.gz: Passed`
`PKG-INFO` correctly contains `Description-Content-Type: text/markdown`

3. Install Twine 1.13.0 and build
```
pip install twine==1.13.0
python setup.py sdist
twine check dist/*
```


This will result in 

```
Checking distribution dist/mypackage.tar.gz: warning: `long_description_content_type` missing.  defaulting to `text/x-rst`.
Passed
```

`PKG-INFO` is missing `Description-Content-Type: text/markdown`.

[PKG-INFO.txt](https://github.com/pypa/twine/files/2869417/PKG-INFO.txt)

items.title: twine is slow to install
items.body:
When I `pip install twine` in a reasonable small virtualenv, Python 3.7.2, pip pulls and installs total of 10 packages (a few dependencies were already installed).

`Installing collected packages: pkginfo, idna, urllib3, chardet, certifi, requests, tqdm, requests-toolbelt, docutils, Pygments, webencodings, bleach, readme-renderer, twine`

At least docutils appears to be build during install (non-default options? sdist?)

This is kinda slow and doesn't feel nice.
I wonder if and how this can be improved.

For comparison, using twine is just awesome!

items.body:
## Your Environment
1) Your operating system:
Arch linux
2) Version of python you are running:
`Python 3.7.1`

3) How did you install twine? Did you use your operating system's package manager or pip or something else?
`pip`

4) Version of twine you have installed (include complete output of):
`1.12.1`

5) Which package repository are you targeting?
Pypi (`upload.pypi/org/legacy`)


## The Issue
Keyring support is fixed in [this commit](https://github.com/pypa/twine/commit/360401bccbe0ae0628c2b1a9304262f5ac033efc).
This fix is released in tag [`1.12.2`](https://github.com/pypa/twine/tree/1.12.2).
However, release `1.12.2` hasn't been [released to Pypi](https://pypi.org/project/twine/#history)

## Steps to Reproduce
`pip install twine`

Metadata-Version: 1.1
Name: kayobe

Home-page: https://kayobe.readthedocs.io/en/latest/
Author: OpenStack
Author-email: openstack-dev@lists.openstack.org
License: UNKNOWN
Description: ======
        Kayobe
        ======
        
        Kayobe enables deployment of containerised OpenStack to bare metal.
        
        Containers offer a compelling solution for isolating OpenStack services, but
        running the control plane on an orchestrator such as Kubernetes or Docker
        Swarm adds significant complexity and operational overheads.
        
        The hosts in an OpenStack control plane must somehow be provisioned, but
        deploying a secondary OpenStack cloud to do this seems like overkill.
        
        Kayobe stands on the shoulders of giants:
        
        * OpenStack bifrost discovers and provisions the cloud
        * OpenStack kolla builds container images for OpenStack services
        * OpenStack kolla-ansible delivers painless deployment and upgrade of
          containerised OpenStack services
        
        To this solid base, kayobe adds:
        
        * Configuration of cloud host OS & flexible networking
        * Management of physical network devices
        * A friendly openstack-like CLI
        
        All this and more, automated from top to bottom using Ansible.
        
        * Free software: Apache license
        * Documentation: https://kayobe.readthedocs.io/en/latest/
        * Source: https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/kayobe
        * Bugs: https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/project/openstack/kayobe
        * Release Notes: https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/kayobe
        * IRC: #openstack-kayobe
        
        Features
        --------
        
        * Heavily automated using Ansible
        * *kayobe* Command Line Interface (CLI) for cloud operators
        * Deployment of a *seed* VM used to manage the OpenStack control plane
        * Configuration of physical network infrastructure
        * Discovery, introspection and provisioning of control plane hardware using
          `OpenStack bifrost <https://docs.openstack.org/bifrost/latest/>`_
        * Deployment of an OpenStack control plane using `OpenStack kolla-ansible
          <https://docs.openstack.org/kolla-ansible/latest/>`_
        * Discovery, introspection and provisioning of bare metal compute hosts
          using `OpenStack ironic <https://docs.openstack.org/ironic/latest/>`_ and
          `ironic inspector <https://docs.openstack.org/ironic-inspector/latest/>`_
        * Virtualised compute using `OpenStack nova
          <https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/>`_
        * Containerised workloads on bare metal using `OpenStack magnum
          <https://docs.openstack.org/magnum/latest/>`_
        * Big data on bare metal using `OpenStack sahara
          <https://docs.openstack.org/sahara/latest/>`_
        
        In the near future we aim to add support for the following:
        
        * Control plane and workload monitoring and log aggregation using `OpenStack
          monasca <https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Monasca>`_

but from the looks of the (spec)[https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0314/#description-optional] the generated output looks OK.

If the issue is predictable and consistently reproducible, please list the steps here.

items.title: "twine check" is emitting a UserWarning when executed because it's misusing readme_renderer
items.body:
1) Your operating system:

macOS 10.14

2) Version of python you are running:

3.7.0

3) How did you install twine? Did you use your operating system's package manager or pip or something else?

pip

4) Version of twine you have installed (include complete output of):

1.12.1

## The Issue
Please describe the issue that you are experiencing.

Twine is unconditionally importing `readme_renderer.markdown` but is not depending on `readme_renderer[md]`, thus triggering a `UserWarning` when `twine check` is executed.

## Steps to Reproduce

run `twine check` and observe 

```
/path/to/virtualenv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/readme_renderer/markdown.py:38: UserWarning: Markdown renderers are not available. Install 'readme_render[md]' to enable Markdown rendering.
  warnings.warn(_EXTRA_WARNING)
```

## Proposed fix

Do not import `readme_renderer.markdown` unless the content-type `text/markdown` is found. Then when validation fails the user sees the warning and knows they need to install the extra dependency.

https://github.com/pypa/twine/blob/bd1d8b0f3ffdae9b91672d075d58cf635aa0e0f6/twine/commands/check.py#L27

items.title: Support keyring.get_username_and_password
items.body:
The next release of keyring will include a [get_username_and_password](https://github.com/jaraco/keyring/issues/350) API that allows backends to return both a username and password for a URL.

By updating twine to use this API, we can enable backends for private feeds to use other mechanisms besides simple username/passwords to authenticate users.

items.title: Officially support Python 3.7
items.body:
- [x] Test against 3.7
- [x] Add Python 3.7 classifier

items.title: Support external credential managers
items.body:
(This proposal is a counterpart to https://github.com/pypa/pip/issues/4475 for pip - enable the same authentication methods for publishing/installing from private feeds)

See https://git-scm.com/docs/api-credentials and https://git-scm.com/docs/git-credential for overviews of git's protocol for using external credential managers.

For example, we would want to offer a credential manager that generates temporary tokens for upload to a private feed, so that we can use other authorization besides the user's name and password on private feeds.

If you have any preferences for how to integrate this, happy to take suggestions. Hopefully it can be achieved in the same way for both pip and twine.

items.title: Release new version
Consider reverting #248
items.body:
While I understand the motivation for the changes introduced in #248 ("Rework handling and display of exceptions"), I think they should probably reverted, and a different approach to solving #228 be taken instead (like specifically handling this edge case rather than applying it to all exceptions).

Suppressing the entire stack trace causes two problems:

#### 1. Difficult to debug user problems
For example, in #383, as a maintainer, I have no idea where this exception is getting raised from because the stack trace has been suppressed. The user has even less of an idea where to look to solve the problem themselves.

#### 2. Difficult to work on `twine`
As a contributor, I need to uncomment these changes in order to do development on twine, when I may occasionally make a mistake and raise an exception from somewhere. Not having the stacktrace available slows me down as a contributor.

I'm happy to do the work as proposed, but wanted to raise this for discussion first before forging ahead. (cc @dstufft @sigmavirus24 @brainwane).

Hi,

Twine denies uploading to untrusted https PyPI clones. This triggers an SSL error caused by an unknown CA certificate. I need the ability to upload packages to untrusted private PyPI servers since 

Backgroung : I'm in process to add PyPI and NPM support to a Nexus server that's published in production with regular CA signed certificates. But  can't obtain such certificates for the Nexus test site.

I made a small quick'n'dirty patch setting `verify=False` option when posting a tarball or wheel file here.

items.title: Add disable progress bar option
items.body: While it's nice to have a progress bar when executing twine interactively, it would be nice to have the option of not displaying the progress bar for those of us who want to redirect twine's output to a file or otherwise use it in a non-interactive way. tqdm has a disable flag: https://github.com/tqdm/tqdm#documentation so it should quite simple to implement.
